(40) 281stConclusions,Minute 1.)Air Operations.naval operations.TheMediterranean.MilitaryOperations:italy -GreeceEgypt.The Chief of the Imperial General Staff reported that thelatest reports stated that there had been no change in the generalsituation. In the Pindus sector the Greeks claimed some localadvance, but the situation was still obscure. In the Epirus sectorthere had been unconfirmed reports of the destruction of nine enemytanks on the Argyrocastro Road. There had been heavy bombingby the Italians on the 2nd November, but on the 3rd November air activity had been less. Three enemy bombers had been shot down at Salonika.There had been a report from Corfu of a naval action west of; . the coast. One unidentified ship had been seen to sink in flames.The first British aircraft had arrived in Greece on the previous day and would fly over Athens.There had been reports of large enemy concentrations at Bariand Brindisi.Two days previously a concentration of about 1,500 M.T.vehicles had been observed in the Bardia area. It was now thoughtthat there were well over 3,000 M.T. vehicles between Sidi Barraniand Bardia. This fact, coupled with recent increased enemyreconnaissance and wireless activity in the forward areas and the reported completion of forward dumps and water cisterns at BuqBuq, suggested the possibility of a further advance. On the otherhand there were other signs which pointed to any further Italianadvance being for a short distance only. Thus the water pipe-line[21890-2] b 21. The Chief of the Air Staff reported that enemy attacksover the week-end had been on a low scale. The casualties on the2nd November in fighting over this country had been : Our Own 2 machines (1 pilot safe).Enemy 15 certain.1 probable.8 damaged.We had also lost 7 aircraft in the bomber and coastal commands.The above figures included four enemy machines shot down onthe night of the 2nd-3rd by A.A. fire.Three Wellingtons had bombed Naples the previous night from malta. Two other Wellingtons taking off to bomb Naples hadcrashed. No detailed report had yet been received. It must beremembered that ground staff had been improvised for theWellingtons at Malta, and were unacquainted with this type of machine.The Chief of Naval Staff said that the A.M.C.'s Laurentic andPatroclus had been torpedoed and, it was believed, sunk west ofBlacksod Bay on the night of the 3rd November when returning from Patrol. The S.S. Casanare had also been torpedoed and sunkearlier in the evening in the same area. Four destroyers, tugs anda Sunderland aircraft had been sent to their assistance.Two U-boats had been sunk in the North-Western Approachesduring the previous week and their crews captured.The Moreton Bay was escorting the French ship Cuba toFreetown and had been about 900 miles from her destination at8 p.m. on the previous evening. Dragon and Alwyn had been dispatched to join her and Royal Sovereign would proceed tosupport after fuelling at Freetown.There had been a number of enemy air attacks on East Coastconvoys, but no casualties had resulted.The War Cabinet were given information regarding the move-ments of the Fleet in the Eastern Mediterranean. had not been completed and it was thought that only one BlackshirtDivision plus two Libyan Divisions plus Tank and Maletti Groupscould be maintained in the forward areas.The "War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Greece.military assistance.(previous reference:W.M. The Minister had a number of useful contacts with Vichy,and his presence there would be very helpful. As soon as the assent of the Canadian Government had been obtained, he proposed toask the Minister to proceed to Vichy without delay.The War Cabinet approved this proposal.Spain- 5. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for Dominion Affairs (W.P. (G.) (40) 277),relating to a suggestion by the Prime Minister of Australia that aConference of Prime Ministers should be held in London, whichhe himself would be willing to attend. In view of replies receivedfrom Dominion Prime Ministers in April last, when such aConference had been proposed, the Secretary of State suggested thatwe might reply to Mr. Menzies pointing out the difficulties of arranging a Conference at present, but indicating that we should welcome a visit by him to London. The Secretary of State attached,for consideration, a draft telegram to our High Commissioner onthese lines.The War Cabinet :-Approved the despatch to the United Kingdom HighCommissioner in the Commonwealth of Australia of thedraft telegram appended to W.P. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theHome Secretary summarising the information obtained as to theprincipal holders of shares in the Daily Mirror and Sunday Pictorial(W.P. (40) 430). This information indicated that no individual,or group of individuals, controlled the policy of these papers bymeans of a preponderating financial interest.The Home Secretary, who explained that his Paper was circulated for information only, said that the tone of these twonewspapers had shown a marked improvement since the interviewswhich the Lord Privy Seal and the Minister of Aircraft production had had with the Newspaper Proprietors' Association and with therepresentatives of these two journals.The War Cabinet took note of this information.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,November 4, 1940.
